issues.description: The problem statement contains an internal contradiction about the parameter type of addGuestStudents: the textual task description states addGuestStudents(String) (line 50), while the UML diagram specifies addGuestStudents(int): void (lines 72-73). The solution implements addGuestStudents(int). This mismatch can confuse students about which parameter type to implement (String vs int).
issues.suggested_fix: Make the parameter type consistent across the problem statement, template, and solution. Update the textual task description (problem_statement.md line 50) to specify addGuestStudents(int) to match the UML and the solution implementation. Alternatively, if a String is intended, change the UML and solution to use String and explain how the method should parse or handle the input. The recommended fix is to use int for addGuestStudents to match the UML and solution.

issues.description: The problem statement text (lines 49-51) describes the method as addGuestStudents(String), while the UML (lines 72-73) and the solution implementation (Lecture.java) use addGuestStudents(int). This mismatch between the textual task description and the UML/solution creates ambiguity about the expected parameter type and may lead students to implement the wrong method signature (String vs int) or be uncertain which representation to follow.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the problem statement text with the UML and solution by changing the textual description to use addGuestStudents(int). Also ensure the template Lecture.java includes or documents the expected method signature (public void addGuestStudents(int)) so students have an unambiguous target to implement. If the intended parameter type was actually String, update the UML and solution consistently instead.
